What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about how harmony works in pop music and how to analyze pop songs

A wide breadth of metrics by which to analyze and classify pop songs. Helped me to listen more critically and think about the interactions between each element of a pop song (how do lyrics reflect the melody, how does form influence a song etc etc)
My theory knowledge and guitar playing definitely improved as I was able to analyze songs i enjoyed.
Looking at popular music theory through a critical and analytical lens
greater coherency of common pop-music constructions
I developed knowledge in analyzing popular music in ways that were different from classical music theory, as well as just more knowledge about the different facets of pop music over the years.
greater knowledge of harmony, melody, meter, rhyme, form, etc. in various types of top music. Also enjoyed some thought-provoking discussions about copyright laws and intellectual property.
an overview of modern music theory

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Everything was good. The only suggestion I'd have would be to have the last part of the class more planned out, but we were all really tired, so I didn't mind.

Strengths: Though the class was technically a lecture, students were strongly encouraged to participate. Wasnt fully a seminar but Professor Adam asked the class plenty of open questions and was more than happy to allow students to chime in with their own knowledge or to let them steer the discussion a little.
Weaknesses: Not necessarily a weakness for everyone, but you should definitely feel very comfortable with your listening skills (identifying meter, chords/progressions etc) immediately on the spot in order to get the most from the class.

I love the fact that it was not particularly rigid in structure and length itself well to interesting and enjoyable discussions. However this was some thing of a double edged sword because some structure may have been slightly more useful for those with less musical experience.
I almost wish the class met three times per week instead of two, or if there were slightly more small assignments.

I really can't think of any clear weaknesses - it was engaging at all times, the content was interesting, the faculty and TA always were looking for suggestions and input from students, and the final paper/project was fun and incorporated many aspects of the course! I would say maybe make the reading components fit more with the course (just to approach it from an academic perspective so we're ready for the final paper)?

We listened to a lot of different music from the course to illustrate different theoretical points which I thoroughly enjoyed - "pop" is so broad that so much music can fall into this category. I would have enjoyed more practice with melodic/harmonic/rhythmic transcription but great class overall.
more individual discussion sessions

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Given the courses entirely discussion-based format, technical difficulties could very easily and occasionally did get in the way. Im sure this problem will be alleviated next year when learning occurs in person
I think the class was generally very engaging despite covid.
Most things pretty much succeeded! Listening and in class discussions flowed smoothly, as well as Canvas assignments/discussions.
screen/audio sharing always went very smoothly, worked well for this class!
I thought the virtuality was fine

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely. Nate is a great professor, he's super knowledgable and prioritizes learning over homework. It can be a little boring at times if you already know a lot of theory, but applying theory is really fun. I'd recommend having taken/taking ear training if you don't have perfect pitch, it'd make parts of the course easier to engage with.
Yes, if you already have a strong background in music theory & listening skills and would like to apply that to pop music!
I would recommend it, but only if the student has interest in musicianship.
Yes!!
Absolutely
Absolutely highlight of my week
Yes! The topic was extremely fun and engaging, plus the fact that students often chose what music they want to analyze helps a lot.
Yes, interesting music class with relatively low workload

Absolutely - if you are interesting in just classical music theory and don't have much interest in pop music, this is also a great way to branch out and challenge yourself with unfamiliar music/concepts!
Yes.

Absolutely! It's a great way to break out of the classical tradition that dominates so much of music in academia. Great for anyone who has an interest in contemporary music/music that goes beyond classical and jazz.
Absolutely! This class is wonderful for exploring the mechanics and theory of pop music
yes, it is a very nice class with a light workload
